Sure, here are some examples of things that individuals, parents, teachers, therapists, financial advisory team, mentor, and best friend can each do in the individual's life, one per role per year from ages 20-25 to set them up for wealth and good money management:

Age 20:

Individual: Start building an emergency fund that covers at least six months of living expenses.

Parent: Encourage the child to start contributing to a retirement plan and explain the importance of compound interest.

Teacher: Teach children about the different types of financial aid for graduate school and how to apply for it.

Therapist: Help children develop healthy coping strategies for financial stress and anxiety.

Financial Advisory Team: Provide guidance on investment strategies for long-term financial goals, such as buying a house or saving for retirement.

Mentor: Share personal finance experiences and offer guidance on financial decisions.

Best Friend: Hold the individual accountable for sticking to their budget and financial goals.

Age 21:

Individual: Learn about the different types of insurance, such as health and auto insurance, and how to choose the right coverage.

Parent: Encourage the child to start saving for a down payment on a house.

Teacher: Teach children about the importance of diversifying investments and how to create a diversified investment portfolio.

Therapist: Help children develop healthy boundaries around money and learn how to say "no" to unnecessary expenses.

Financial Advisory Team: Evaluate the individual's investment portfolio and provide recommendations for rebalancing it.

Mentor: Share personal experiences about how to handle financial setbacks and offer guidance on building credit.

Best Friend: Offer support and encouragement to stay on track with financial goals.

Age 22:

Individual: Create a debt repayment plan and learn about different debt repayment strategies.

Parent: Encourage the child to learn about the tax implications of investments and how to minimize taxes.

Teacher: Teach children about the importance of negotiating a salary and how to do it effectively.

Therapist: Help children develop a healthy relationship with money and understand how it impacts their mental health.

Financial Advisory Team: Help the individual and their family create a comprehensive estate plan, including wills and trusts.

Mentor: Share personal finance experiences related to job changes and career advancement.

Best Friend: Offer support and encouragement to stay focused on financial goals.

Age 23:

Individual: Learn about the importance of maintaining good credit and how to improve credit score if necessary.

Parent: Encourage the child to start investing in a tax-advantaged retirement account, such as a Roth IRA.

Teacher: Teach children about the different types of investment accounts and how to choose the right one for their goals.

Therapist: Help children develop a positive mindset around money and learn how to celebrate financial successes.

Financial Advisory Team: Help the individual and their family review and update their investment strategy based on changing financial goals and market conditions.

Mentor: Offer guidance on building a professional network and creating career opportunities that lead to financial growth.

Best Friend: Offer support and encouragement to stay committed to long-term financial goals.

Age 24:

Individual: Create a comprehensive financial plan that includes short-term and long-term goals.

Parent: Encourage the child to create a will and establish power of attorney in case of emergency.

Teacher: Teach children about the importance of creating a diverse investment portfolio and how to rebalance it as needed.

Therapist: Help children develop a healthy sense of self-worth that is not tied to their financial status.

Financial Advisory Team: Provide guidance on how to manage investment risks and how to stay focused on long-term goals during market fluctuations.

Mentor: Offer guidance on building a successful career and managing financial success.

Best Friend: Offer support and encouragement to stay motivated and on track with financial goals.
